Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Chemistry with Simple Tetrahedral Building Blocks: Synthesis and Study of Bulk and Nanocrystalline Diamond-Like Semiconductors with Novel Optical & Magnetic Propertie
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL EXPLANATION

The goal of this project is to synthesize and characterize new diamond-like semiconductors (DLS) and dilute magnetic semiconductors with diamond-like structures. DLS are a particularly attractive category of materials to pursue because they have potential applications in a variety of fields. The preparation of these materials will be carried out using four synthetic strategies: microwave irradiation, solvothermal reaction, molten metal growth and high-temperature solid-state synthesis. Targeted materials have been carefully chosen based upon theoretical predictions that these compounds should possess interesting properties. The optical, electrical and magnetic properties of these new semiconductors will be systematically studied as a function of composition and structure. The compositional flexibility in these systems will allow for the tuning of physical properties. This research has the potential to bring us closer to the realization of new materials for specialized non-linear optical applications and spin-based devices that function near room temperature. The proposed project integrates research and education in several ways, such as development of new courses in materials chemistry, graduate and undergraduate research, minority high school student summer research and outreach activities geared towards women and minorities.

NON-TECHNICAL EXPLANATION

Diamond-like semiconductors are important materials because they exhibit a variety of useful applications. This project focuses on preparing these materials via both traditional and nontraditional avenues and measuring their properties. The proposed research has broader impacts in its potential to affect technologies that rely heavily upon materials with unique optical and magnetic characteristics, by identifying new compounds with the desired properties. New nonlinear optical materials prepared through this project have potential uses in the areas of spectroscopy, medicine and remote sensing. Magnetic semiconductors prepared through this project could potentially benefit numerous technologies, including IC (integrated circuit) cards, missile control and quantum computing. Graduate, undergraduate and high school students involved in this project will be trained for careers in government, academic, pharmaceutical, chemical and crime laboratories. New courses will be developed to strengthen the department's materials chemistry curriculum. This project will broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in science through the Project SEED program for economically disadvantaged high school students, many of whom are minorities, and the Women in Science program at Duquesne University for graduate and undergraduate female students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on the synthesis of diamond-like semiconductors (DLSs) and magnetic semiconductors with diamond-like structures, as well as a thorough investigation of their properties. Over thirty diamond-like semiconductors were studied and thirteen scientific manuscripts were published based on this work. Through this project, we have gathered a better understanding of the methods to prepare these materials as both powders and single crystals and we have overcome difficulties in determining their structures, i.e. describing the arrangements of the ions in the semiconductor materials. In many cases we have succeeded in related the structure of these materials to the physical properties that have been revealed. We have improved materials capable of converting waste heat into energy and materials that are capable of doubling the frequency of an incident laser.

The PI of this project has delivered over a dozen seminars and presentations at regional, national and international meetings to help disseminate the findings. Two visiting faculty members, two post-doctoral fellows, seven graduate students, twelve undergraduate students, one high school chemistry teacher and one high school student have participated in the project and received mentoring and training. These individuals have delivered over forty-five presentations at conferences. Graduate students working on this project have travelled to the Advanced Photon Source at Argonne National Laboratory and the Spallation Neutron Source at Oak Ridge National Laboratory to perform experiments to aid this project. Outreach activities included: the American Chemical Society Project SEED program, a series of National Chemistry Week demonstrations for the pre-K class at Duquesne University's daycare center, demonstrations for the Girls in Science Club at Winchester Thurston School (grades 5th-8th), demonstrations at Sto-Rox High School, a free workshop in X-ray crystallography, and a women in chemistry workshop about graduate school, among several others. This project has enable new collaborations, and strengthened existing collaborations, with near-by, primarily undergraduate institutions, such as Washington and Jefferson College, St. Vincent College, California University of PA, Indiana University of PA and Chatham University.
